Chapter 2
Naïve Set Theory

mmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm mmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm mmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm mmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm mmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm mmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm

In the previous chapter we examined how to formulate, prove, and disprove statements. The example statements we looked at talked about numbers and squirrel, but the principles we examined apply regardless of which objects the statements talk about. In this chapter, we examine a class of objects that is so powerful that we can express everything from numbers to computers to proofs themselves in it. This class of objects will provide the foundation for everything we will study throughout this book.

Such a universal domain will allow us to apply very general concepts to arbitrarily specific situations. And yet you will find that the objects our statements will talk about are in themselves very simple. Striking that balance between simplicity and universality of foundational objects was arguably one of the key achievements of the 20th century: the development of set theory.

2.1: Sets

When attempting to define the foundations of mathematics, you run into a chicken-egg problem: Any definition needs to make use of mathematical concepts, so in particular the definition of the foundational objects also requires prior definitions. But then it clearly is not foundational.

While there are sophisticated ways of avoiding this problem, they require a good understanding of mathematics to begin with. So we instead follow the traditional approach in teaching: Our very first definition will be slightly informal, and we will simply pretend that it was sufficiently precise. Hence the naïve in the chapter title naïve set theory.

In particular, we will talk about mathematical objects, without specifically stating what those are. For our purposes, we require that an object is equal to itself but not to anything else. The number 17,17\text{,}17, for example, is a mathematical object.

Furthermore, an object must be well-defined, that is, it must be clear, for the purposes of determining equality, which object you are talking about. For example, the most important composer of the 18th century is not well-defined; whether the most important composer of the 18th century is equal to Johann Sebastian Bach is a matter of personal opinion, not of mathematical reasoning.

We will use squirrel-related iconography for our mathematical objects: ,,,,\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol0}{}}, \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol1}{}}, \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol2}{}}, \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol3}{}}\text{,},,,, and .\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol4}{}}\text{.}. We know that =,≠,\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol0}{}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/deductive_reasoning.html#eq}{=}} \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol0}{}}, \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol0}{}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/neq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/deductive_reasoning.html#neq}{\neq}} \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol1}{}}\text{,}=,=, and so on, and these are the only properties we ascribe to those symbols.

With that out of the way, it is time to look at the one definition upon which everything else in this book will build:

Definition 2.1: Set

A set is a collection of objects, characterized solely by which objects belong to it, and which objects do not.

We denote a set by listing its objects within curly braces, separated by commas, for example: {,,}. \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol0}{}}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol1}{}}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol2}{}} \right\rbrace \text{.}{,,}.

The empty set {} \left\lbrace \right\rbrace {} — the collection that contains no objects at all — is also written as ∅.\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set}{\emptyset}}\text{.}∅.

Because a set is characterized by the objects that belong to it, {,} \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol0}{}}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol1}{}} \right\rbrace {,} and {,} \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol1}{}}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol0}{}} \right\rbrace {,} are two different ways of denoting the same set. Informally speaking, sets ignore the order of their objects. Furthermore, {,,} \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol0}{}}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol1}{}}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol0}{}} \right\rbrace {,,} and {,} \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol0}{}}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol1}{}} \right\rbrace {,} also denote the same set, you could say that sets ignore duplicates. All three expressions are simply different ways of denoting the unique mathematical object characterized by the fact that \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol0}{}} and \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol1}{}} belong to it, but nothing else does.

After the build-up about the foundational concept that is able to express anything you could possibly dream up, the notion of sets might be a bit of a letdown at first glance. We will get to the reasons for why sets are a very powerful concept soon enough, but first, we define and inspect some elementary terminology and notation.

Definition 2.2: Set Membership

To express that an object xxx occurs in a set X,X\text{,}X, we write x∈X,x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} X\text{,}x∈X, and we say that xxx is an element of XXX, xxx is a member of XXX, or simply that xxx in XXX.

If not x∈X,x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} X\text{,}x∈X, we write x∉X.x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\notin}} X\text{.}x∈/X.

Example 2.3
∈{,},\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol0}{}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol0}{}}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol1}{}} \right\rbrace \text{,}∈{,}, ∈{,},\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol1}{}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol0}{}}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol1}{}} \right\rbrace \text{,}∈{,}, and ∉{,}.\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol2}{}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\notin}} \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol0}{}}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol1}{}} \right\rbrace \text{.}∈/{,}.

We can visualize set membership by drawing sets as blobs that enclose their elements. Example 2.4 demonstrates such an Euler diagram. Note how the idea of a set containing elements multiple times or in a particular order cannot even be expressed in these depictions, making Euler diagrams a more faithful representations of sets than our written notation.

Set Equality

Based on the notion of set membership, we can define precisely when two sets are considered equal.

Definition 2.5: Set Equality

Let AAA and BBB be sets.

We say AAA and BBB are equal, written as A=B,A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} B\text{,}A=B, if for each xxx holds that x∈Ax \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Ax∈A if and only if x∈B.x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} B\text{.}x∈B.

If not A=B,A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} B\text{,}A=B, we write A≠B.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{\neq}} B\text{.}A=B.

Take a moment to consider some equivalent formulations for the if and only if in Definition 2.5:

  • A=BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} BA=B if every x∈Ax \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Ax∈A is in BBB and every x∈Bx \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Bx∈B is in A.A\text{.}A.
  • A=BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} BA=B if every x∈Ax \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Ax∈A is in BBB and every x∉Ax \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\notin}} Ax∈/A is not in B.B\text{.}B.
  • A=BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} BA=B if every xxx is either in both AAA and BBB or in neither.

All of these ways of looking at set equality can come in handy when trying to prove that two complex descriptions of sets actually describe the same one. Example 2.6 visualizes the third interpretation.

Two sets, with the elements that occur in exactly one of them are highlighted. You can change the sets, note how the sets are equal exactly if no such highlighted elements remain.

Equipped with a precise definition of set equality, we can now prove some fundamental properties of equal sets.

Theorem 2.7: Reflexivity of =\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{=}=

Let AAA be a set, then A=AA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} AA=A.

Proof of Theorem  2.7
a∈A  ⟹  a∈Aa \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/implication.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/deductive_reasoning.html#implication}{\implies}} a \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Aa∈A⟹a∈A:

Let a∈A,a \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} A\text{,}a∈A, then a∈Aa \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Aa∈A by assumption.

a∉A  ⟹  a∉Aa \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\notin}} A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/implication.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/deductive_reasoning.html#implication}{\implies}} a \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\notin}} Aa∈/A⟹a∈/A:

Theorem 2.8: Symmetry of =\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{=}=

Let A,BA, BA,B be sets. If A=B,A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} B\text{,}A=B, then B=A.B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} A\text{.}B=A.

Proof of Theorem  2.8

Assume that A=B,A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} B\text{,}A=B, that is, assume that x∈Ax \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Ax∈A implies x∈B,x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} B\text{,}x∈B, and that x∈Bx \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Bx∈B implies x∈A.x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} A\text{.}x∈A. Then by the commutativity of conjunctions we also have that x∈Bx \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Bx∈B implies x∈Ax \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Ax∈A and x∈Ax \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Ax∈A implies x∈B,x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} B\text{,}x∈B, that is, B=A.B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} A\text{.}B=A.

Theorem 2.9: Transitivity of =\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{=}=

Let A,B,CA, B, CA,B,C be sets. If A=BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} BA=B and B=C,B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} C\text{,}B=C, then A=C.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} C\text{.}A=C.

Proof of Theorem  2.9

Assume that A=BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} BA=B and B=C.B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} C\text{.}B=C.

These properties might feel so self-evidently true (just picture the Euler diagrams) that it can initially be hard to know where to even begin proving them. So while these proofs might not be the most flashy ones, it is quite remarkable that we can rigorously reason about such fundamental properties rather than having to blindly accept them as true.

Exercise 2.1

Let A,B,CA, B, CA,B,C be sets. Prove or disprove: if A≠BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{\neq}} BA=B and B≠C,B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{\neq}} C\text{,}B=C, then A≠C.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{\neq}} C\text{.}A=C.

We disprove the statement by giving a counterexample. Define A≔{},B≔{},A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/defeq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/deductive_reasoning.html#defeq}{\coloneqq}} \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol0}{}} \right\rbrace , B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/defeq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/deductive_reasoning.html#defeq}{\coloneqq}} \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol1}{}} \right\rbrace \text{,}A:={},B:={}, and C≔{}.C \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/defeq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/deductive_reasoning.html#defeq}{\coloneqq}} \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol0}{}} \right\rbrace \text{.}C:={}. Then A≠BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{\neq}} BA=B (because ∈A\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol0}{}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} A∈A but ∉B\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol0}{}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\notin}} B∈/B), B≠CB \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{\neq}} CB=C (because ∈B\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol1}{}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} B∈B but ∉C\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol1}{}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\notin}} C∈/C), but A=C.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} C\text{.}A=C.

The definition of set equality also justifies why we talk about the empty set and not an empty set. The set of numbers that are both less than 12 and greater than 17, and the set of unicorns on the international space station, are precisely the same mathematical object.

Subsets

We can think of set equality as a very strict way of looking for similarity between two sets. But there are more general ways in which sets can be related. It might be the case, for example, that one set contains all elements of another set, but not necessarily the other way around. This relation is common enough that we give it a name:

Definition 2.10: Subset, Superset

Let AAA and BBB be sets.

We say AAA is a subset of B,B\text{,}B, written as A⊆B,A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} B\text{,}A⊆B, if for each x∈Ax \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Ax∈A holds x∈B.x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} B\text{.}x∈B.

Conversely, we say that BBB is a superset of A,A\text{,}A, written as B⊇A,B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\supseteq}} A\text{,}B⊇A, if A⊆B.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} B\text{.}A⊆B.

We further write A⊈BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\nsubseteq}} BA⊈B if not A⊆B,A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} B\text{,}A⊆B, and A⊉BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\nsupseteq}} BA⊉B if not A⊇B.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\supseteq}} B\text{.}A⊇B.

Explore Example 2.11 for a bit. What do you expect to happen if both sets are equal? What if one of them is empty?

Two sets and the subset and superset relations between them.

If you compare the definitions of set equality and subsets, you can see that the definition of subsets is essentially one direction of the bi-implication in the definition of set equality. In other words, two sets are equal if they are both subsets and supersets of each other. Formally:

Observation 2.12
A=BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} BA=B if and only if A⊆BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} BA⊆B and A⊇B.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\supseteq}} B\text{.}A⊇B.
Proof of Observation  2.12
A=B  ⟹  A⊆BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/implication.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/deductive_reasoning.html#implication}{\implies}} A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} BA=B⟹A⊆B and A⊇BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\supseteq}} BA⊇B:

Assume A=B.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} B\text{.}A=B. We now show that A⊆BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} BA⊆B and A⊇B.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\supseteq}} B\text{.}A⊇B.

Let a∈A,a \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} A\text{,}a∈A, then a∈B,a \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} B\text{,}a∈B, because A=B.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} B\text{.}A=B. Thus, A⊆B.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} B\text{.}A⊆B.

Analogously, let b∈B,b \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} B\text{,}b∈B, then b∈A,b \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} A\text{,}b∈A, because A=B.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} B\text{.}A=B. Thus, A⊇B.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\supseteq}} B\text{.}A⊇B.

A⊆BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} BA⊆B and A⊇B  ⟹  A=BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\supseteq}} B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/implication.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/deductive_reasoning.html#implication}{\implies}} A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} BA⊇B⟹A=B:

Assume that A⊆BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} BA⊆B and A⊇B.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\supseteq}} B\text{.}A⊇B. We now show that A=B.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} B\text{.}A=B.

a∈A  ⟹  a∈Ba \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/implication.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/deductive_reasoning.html#implication}{\implies}} a \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Ba∈A⟹a∈B:
Let a∈A,a \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} A\text{,}a∈A, then a∈B,a \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} B\text{,}a∈B, because A⊆B.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} B\text{.}A⊆B.
b∈B  ⟹  b∈Ab \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/implication.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/deductive_reasoning.html#implication}{\implies}} b \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Ab∈B⟹b∈A:
Let b∈B,b \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} B\text{,}b∈B, then b∈A,b \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} A\text{,}b∈A, because A⊇B.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\supseteq}} B\text{.}A⊇B.

This alternate characterization offers yet another way of proving set equality.

If you played around a bit with Example 2.11, you may have noticed that the empty set is a subset of every set. To understand why, we need to take a close look at how subsets are defined. The definition talks about all x∈Ax \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Ax∈A, so what happens if A=∅?A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set}{\emptyset}}\text{?}A=∅? There exists no xxx such that x∈∅,x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set}{\emptyset}}\text{,}x∈∅, so what does that mean for the definition?

On an intuitive level, you can say that in order to show that some set is a subset of another, you need to show that a certain property holds for each of its members. As the empty set has no members, you do not need to show anything.

More formally, the phrase for each x∈Ax \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Ax∈A holds bla is a shorthand for for each object xxx holds that x∈Ax \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Ax∈A implies bla. With that knowledge, we can formally prove that the empty set is a subset of every set:

Theorem 2.13

Let AAA be a set, then ∅⊆A.\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set}{\emptyset}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} A\text{.}∅⊆A.

Proof of Theorem  2.13

Let xxx be an object. We need to show that x∈∅x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set}{\emptyset}}x∈∅ implies x∈A,x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} A\text{,}x∈A, so assume that x∈∅.x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set}{\emptyset}}\text{.}x∈∅.

Because the empty set has no members, we know that x∉∅.x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\notin}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set}{\emptyset}}\text{.}x∈/∅. As we cannot have x∈∅x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set}{\emptyset}}x∈∅ and x∉∅x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\notin}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set}{\emptyset}}x∈/∅ simultaneously, x∈Ax \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Ax∈A holds by the principle of explosion.

Whenever a statement of universal quantification holds because it is constrained to elements from the empty set, we say that the statement holds vacuously.

Exercise 2.2

Based on your knowledge about negating universal quantifications, give a full picture of how statements like there exists x∈∅x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set}{\emptyset}}x∈∅ such that bla work out.

Such a statement is always false; intuitively it is impossible to find a witness that is in the empty set.

There exists x∈∅x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set}{\emptyset}}x∈∅ such that bla is equivalent to its double negation it does not hold that there exists no x∈∅x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set}{\emptyset}}x∈∅ such that bla. This in turn is equivalent to it does not hold that for each x∈∅x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set}{\emptyset}}x∈∅ not bla, which is the negation of a vacuously true statement, and thus false.

The concept of subsets is ubiquitous in mathematics, so use the following exercises and theorems to familiarize yourself with it. They also present a good opportunity to practice your deductive reasoning skills.

Exercise 2.3

Give sets A,A\text{,}A, B,B\text{,}B, and C,C\text{,}C, such that A⊆CA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} CA⊆C and B⊆C,B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} C\text{,}B⊆C, but A⊈BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\nsubseteq}} BA⊈B and B⊈A.B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\nsubseteq}} A\text{.}B⊈A.

Exercise 2.4

Prove or disprove: there exist sets A,B,CA, B, CA,B,C such that A⊆B,A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} B\text{,}A⊆B, B⊆C,B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} C\text{,}B⊆C, and C⊆A.C \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} A\text{.}C⊆A.

The statement holds. Define A≔∅,A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/defeq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/deductive_reasoning.html#defeq}{\coloneqq}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set}{\emptyset}}\text{,}A:=∅, B≔∅,B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/defeq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/deductive_reasoning.html#defeq}{\coloneqq}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set}{\emptyset}}\text{,}B:=∅, and C≔∅.C \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/defeq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/deductive_reasoning.html#defeq}{\coloneqq}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set}{\emptyset}}\text{.}C:=∅. Then A⊆B,A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} B\text{,}A⊆B, B⊆C,B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} C\text{,}B⊆C, and C⊆AC \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} AC⊆A by Theorem  2.14.

Bonus exercise: show that for all sets A,B,CA, B, CA,B,C holds that A⊆B,A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} B\text{,}A⊆B, B⊆CB \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} CB⊆C and C⊆AC \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} AC⊆A if and only if A=BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} BA=B and B=C.B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} C\text{.}B=C.

Subsets express that some set contains at least every member of another set. Sometimes we want to express that a set also contains at least one further object:

Definition 2.16: Strict Subset, Strict Superset

Let AAA and BBB be sets.

We say AAA is a strict subset of B,B\text{,}B, written as A⊂B,A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\subset}} B\text{,}A⊂B, if A⊆BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} BA⊆B and A≠B.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{\neq}} B\text{.}A=B.

Conversely, we say AAA is a strict superset of B,B\text{,}B, written as A⊃B,A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\supset}} B\text{,}A⊃B, if A⊇BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\supseteq}} BA⊇B and A≠B.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{\neq}} B\text{.}A=B.

We further write A⊄BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\not\subset}} BA⊂B if not A⊂B,A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\subset}} B\text{,}A⊂B, and A⊅BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\not\supset}} BA⊃B if not A⊃B.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\supset}} B\text{.}A⊃B.

Strict subsets behave similar to (possibly non-strict) subsets, but the following exercises also highlight some differences.

Theorem 2.17: Transitivity of ⊂\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\subset}⊂

Let A,B,CA, B, CA,B,C be sets. If A⊂BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\subset}} BA⊂B and B⊂C,B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\subset}} C\text{,}B⊂C, then A⊂C.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\subset}} C\text{.}A⊂C.

Proof of Theorem  2.17

Let A,B,CA, B, CA,B,C be sets. Assume that A⊂BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\subset}} BA⊂B and B⊂C.B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\subset}} C\text{.}B⊂C.

As every strict subset of a set is also a (not necessarily strict) subset, Theorem  2.15 gives us that A⊆C.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} C\text{.}A⊆C. It remains to show that A≠C.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{\neq}} C\text{.}A=C.

Since A≠BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{\neq}} BA=B but every member of AAA is a member of BBB (both because A⊂BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\subset}} BA⊂B), there exists some x∈Bx \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Bx∈B with x∉A.x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\notin}} A\text{.}x∈/A. Because x∈Bx \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Bx∈B and B⊂C,B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\subset}} C\text{,}B⊂C, we know that x∈Cx \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Cx∈C. And since x∉A,x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\notin}} A\text{,}x∈/A, we get that A≠C.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{\neq}} C\text{.}A=C.

Exercise 2.5

Let A,BA, BA,B be sets. Prove or disprove: if A⊂BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\subset}} BA⊂B and B⊂A,B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\subset}} A\text{,}B⊂A, then A=B.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} B\text{.}A=B.

The statement holds. Its premise can never be fulfilled. We formally prove the statement by assuming the premise to hold, deriving a contradiction, and applying the principle of explosion to show the conclusion.

Assume that A⊂BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\subset}} BA⊂B and B⊂A.B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\subset}} A\text{.}B⊂A. Then a∈Aa \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Aa∈A implies a∈Ba \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Ba∈B (because A⊂BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\subset}} BA⊂B), and furthermore b∈Bb \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Bb∈B implies b∈Ab \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Ab∈A (because B⊂AB \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\subset}} AB⊂A), that is, A=B.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} B\text{.}A=B.

By assumption we also have A≠BA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{\neq}} BA=B as well however, a contradiction. By the principle of explosion, we can follow that A=B,A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} B\text{,}A=B, and have thus proven the statement.

We could have also ended the proof at the end of its second paragraph, as we have already proven the conclusion at that point. The third paragraph merely demonstrates how we can show anything from an impossible premise.

Exercise 2.6

Prove or disprove: there exist sets A,B,CA, B, CA,B,C such that A⊂B,A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\subset}} B\text{,}A⊂B, B⊂C,B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\subset}} C\text{,}B⊂C, and C⊂A.C \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\subset}} A\text{.}C⊂A.

The statement does not hold, so we prove its negation. Let A,B,CA, B, CA,B,C be sets, and suppose toward a contradiction that A⊂B,A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\subset}} B\text{,}A⊂B, B⊂C,B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\subset}} C\text{,}B⊂C, and C⊂A.C \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\subset}} A\text{.}C⊂A.

Because A⊂B,A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\subset}} B\text{,}A⊂B, there exists x∈Bx \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Bx∈B such that x∉A.x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\notin}} A\text{.}x∈/A. Then x∈C,x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} C\text{,}x∈C, because x∈Bx \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Bx∈B and B⊂C.B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\subset}} C\text{.}B⊂C. But then also x∈A,x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} A\text{,}x∈A, because x∈Cx \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Cx∈C and C⊂A,C \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subset}{\subset}} A\text{,}C⊂A, a contradiction.

2.2: Combining Sets

When considering multiple sets, some objects might be in exactly one of them, while others might be in multiple of them. Take, for example, the three sets of species of animals that can walk, swim, or fly respectively. We might be interested in the set of all species that can walk and swim but cannot fly. In this section, we introduce terminology for deriving such sets from other sets.

Figure 2.18 visualizes the example in a Venn diagram, a special type of Euler diagram that shows all possible ways in which some sets can overlap.

Figure 2.18

A Venn diagram showing the sets of animal species that can walk (top), fly (left), and swim (right). Each region shows an icon of a species that belongs to it.

So far, we have only denoted sets by explicitly enumerating their members, which does not help us when trying to define a set in terms of other sets. For that reason, we introduce the set builder notation, in which we specify a set by giving a predicate that is satisfied exactly by the members of the set (read the vertical bar (∣\mid∣) as such that):

{x∣x∈{,,} and x∈{,,}},\big\lbrace x\mid\text{$x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol0}{}}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol1}{}}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol2}{}} \right\rbrace $ and $x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol0}{}}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol2}{}}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol3}{}} \right\rbrace $} \big\rbrace \text{,}{x∣x∈{,,} and x∈{,,}}, for example, is a complicated way of denoting the set {,}. \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol0}{}}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol2}{}} \right\rbrace \text{.}{,}.

As this notation is more of a technicality than an interesting new concept, we shall not dwell on it any further.

Intersection and Union

We now define our terminology for the objects that occur in both of two sets:

Definition 2.19: Intersection

Let A,BA, BA,B be sets. The intersection of AAA and B,B\text{,}B, written as A∩B,A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/intersection.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#intersection}{\cap}} B\text{,}A∩B, is the set of all objects which are elements of both AAA and B:B\text{:}B: A∩B≔{x∣x∈A and x∈B}.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/intersection.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#intersection}{\cap}} B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/defeq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/deductive_reasoning.html#defeq}{\coloneqq}} \left\lbrace x\mid\text{$x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} A$ and $x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} B$} \right\rbrace .A∩B:={x∣x∈A and x∈B}.

If we swap the conjunction for a disjunction in the definition of the intersection of two sets, we obtain another useful concept:

Definition 2.21: Union

Let A,BA, BA,B be sets. Computing such expressions is the bread-and-butter operation of set theory, just like addition and multiplication are for arithmetic. The next exercise gives you ample opportunities to practice, you can generate new expressions and solutions with the click of a button.

Exercise 2.7

Compute

Grouping these expressions with parentheses is necessary in general, because there are expressions for which the exact grouping makes a difference in the result:

Statement 2.23

We call operators for which the grouping makes no difference associative, and we don't require explicit grouping via parentheses for associative operators, so it is fine to write, for example, A∪B∪CA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/union.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#union}{\cup}} B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/union.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#union}{\cup}} CA∪B∪C. In general, you must always provide parentheses with any binary operator, unless the operator in question has been proven to be associative.

The proofs for Theorem  2.24 and Theorem  2.25 are very typical for proving properties about freshly defined concepts: you unfold the definition of the concept until you are only working with older concepts, you use their known properties to prove what you need, and finally you translate it back into the new terminology. In this particular case, intersection and union inherit the associativity of conjunction and disjunction respectively fairly directly. Using structurally similar proofs, we can show that they inherit commutativity as well:

Theorem 2.26: Commutativity of ∩\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/intersection.html}{\cap}∩

Let A,BA, BA,B be sets. Then A∩B=B∩A.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/intersection.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#intersection}{\cap}} B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/intersection.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#intersection}{\cap}} A\text{.}A∩B=B∩A.

Proof of Theorem  2.26

\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} {} & \left\lbrace x\mid\text{$x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} A$ and $x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} B$} \right\rbrace \tag{Definition Two further simple but useful observations are that intersections never add elements, and unions never remove elements:

Theorem 2.28

Let A,BA, BA,B be sets. Then A∩B⊆A.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/intersection.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#intersection}{\cap}} B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} A\text{.}A∩B⊆A.

Proof of Theorem  2.28

Let A,BA, BA,B be sets, and let x∈A∩Bx \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/intersection.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#intersection}{\cap}} Bx∈A∩B. Then also x∈Ax \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Ax∈A by definition of ∩,\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/intersection.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#intersection}{\cap}}\text{,}∩, and thus A∩B⊆A.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/intersection.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#intersection}{\cap}} B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} A\text{.}A∩B⊆A.

Theorem 2.29

Let A,BA, BA,B be sets. Then A⊆A∪B.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/union.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#union}{\cup}} B\text{.}A⊆A∪B.

Proof of Theorem  2.29

Let A,BA, BA,B be sets, and let x∈Ax \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Ax∈A. Then also x∈A∪Bx \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/union.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#union}{\cup}} Bx∈A∪B by definition of ∪,\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/union.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#union}{\cup}}\text{,}∪, and thus A⊆A∪B.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/union.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#union}{\cup}} B\text{.}A⊆A∪B.

The following exercises give you some more opportunities to practice proofs like this.

Exercise 2.9

Let A,B,CA, B, CA,B,C be sets with A⊆CA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} CA⊆C and B⊆C.B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} C\text{.}B⊆C. Theorem 2.30: Absorption of ∩\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/intersection.html}{\cap}∩ and ∪\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/union.html}{\cup}∪

Set Difference

Thinking back to the example of the sets of species of animals that eat plants and those that eat meat, consider the set of true herbivores, that is, the species that eat plants but no meat. Using only intersection and union, it is not possible to describe that set. We thus define a third binary operator:

Definition 2.31: Set Difference

Let A,BA, BA,B be sets. The set difference of AAA and B,B\text{,}B, relative complement of BBB in A,A\text{,}A, or simply AAA without B,B\text{,}B, written as A∖B,A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_difference.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_difference}{\setminus}} B\text{,}A∖B, is the set of all objects which are elements of AAA but not of B:B\text{:}B: A∖B≔{x∣x∈A and x∉B}.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_difference.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_difference}{\setminus}} B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/defeq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/deductive_reasoning.html#defeq}{\coloneqq}} \left\lbrace x\mid\text{$x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} A$ and $x \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\notin}} B$} \right\rbrace .A∖B:={x∣x∈A and x∈/B}.

An immediate observation we can make general properties of the set difference operation is that removing elements from a set always results in a (not necessarily strict) subset:

Theorem 2.33

Let AAA and BBB be sets. Then A∖B⊆A.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_difference.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_difference}{\setminus}} B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} A\text{.}A∖B⊆A.

Proof of Theorem  2.33

Let AAA and BBB be sets, and let x∈A∖Bx \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_difference.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_difference}{\setminus}} Bx∈A∖B. Then also x∈Ax \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Ax∈A by definition of ∖,\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_difference.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_difference}{\setminus}}\text{,}∖, and thus A∖B⊆A.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_difference.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_difference}{\setminus}} B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} A\text{.}A∖B⊆A.

Unlike intersection and union, set difference is sensitive to both the order of the two sets to be combined, and the grouping of multiple set differences.

When computing intersections by hand, a helpful technique is to write down one of the sets and to then cross out the elements that do not occur in the other set. An example: {,,,}∩{,,}={,,,}={,}. \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol0}{}}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol1}{}}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol3}{}}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol4}{}} \right\rbrace \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/intersection.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#intersection}{\cap}} \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol0}{}}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol2}{}}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol3}{}} \right\rbrace \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol0}{}}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{cancel_symbol}{\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol1}{}}}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol3}{}}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{cancel_symbol}{\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol4}{}}} \right\rbrace \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol0}{}}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol3}{}} \right\rbrace .{,,,}∩{,,}={,,,}={,}. We can prove that this technique always yields the correct result — take a moment to think through how the following theorem relates to the technique:

Theorem 2.36

Let AAA and BBB be sets. Sets of Sets

TODO different intro With a solid understanding of the basic predicates of set theory — membership, equality, and being a (strict) subset — under our belt, we can now examine what makes sets so powerful.

A set can contain arbitrary mathematical objects. A set is a mathematical object itself. See where this is going? Sets can contain other sets!

We can have nested sets such as {{,},{,},} \Big\lbrace \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol0}{}}, \allowbreak\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol1}{}} \right\rbrace , Another common source of mistakes is the distinction between an object and the set that contains exactly that object but nothing else. Because we can nest sets arbitrarily deeply, we can represent arbitrarily complex mathematic concepts through sets. Sometimes we do so explicitly by defining things in terms of sets, sometimes we will simply assume implicitly that it would be possible to express concepts in terms of sets. We have been using icons such as ,\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol0}{}}, \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol1}{}},, and \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol2}{}} as mathematic objects for example, but since their only interesting property is how they behave in terms of equality, we might as well have been using the sets ∅,{∅},\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set}{\emptyset}}, \left\lbrace \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set}{\emptyset}} \right\rbrace \text{,}∅,{∅}, and {{∅}}. \left\lbrace \left\lbrace \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set}{\emptyset}} \right\rbrace \right\rbrace \text{.}{{∅}}. Using symbols is more readable, but ultimately not necessary from a purely mathematic standpoint (and expressing everything in terms of pure sets is indeed how more formal approaches to set theory eliminate the problem of having to define objects before being able to define sets).

Power Sets

One particular kind of set of sets that we will encounter repeatedly throughout this book arises from the following question: Given some set XXX, which sets are there that contain no objects but those from XXX (although not necessarily all of them)? This is in fact the same as asking for the set of subsets of XXX — take a moment to think through why that is. It is this viewpoint we use for our proper definition:

Definition 2.37: Power Set

Let XXX be a set. The power set of X,X\text{,}X, written as P⁡(X),\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/powerset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#powerset}{\operatorname{\mathcal{P}}}} \left( X \right) \text{,}P(X), is the set of all subsets of X.X\text{.}X.

Example 2.38: Power Set
A≔{,,}\htmlClass{c1}{A} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/defeq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/deductive_reasoning.html#defeq}{\coloneqq}} \left\lbrace \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol1}{}}, \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol2}{}}, \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol4}{}} \right\rbrace A:={,,}
A∩B={,,}∩{,}={}\htmlClass{c1}{A} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/powerset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#powerset}{\cap}} \htmlClass{c2}{B} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} \left\lbrace \htmlClass{s3}{\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol1}{}}}, \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol2}{}}, \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol4}{}} \right\rbrace \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/powerset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#powerset}{\cap}} \left\lbrace \htmlClass{s3}{\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol1}{}}}, \htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol3}{}} \right\rbrace \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} \left\lbrace \htmlClass{s3}{\htmlClass{symbol_container}{\htmlClass{symbol1}{}}} \right\rbrace A∩B={,,}∩{,}={}

Notice how A⊆UA \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} UA⊆U and A∈P⁡(U)A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/powerset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#powerset}{\operatorname{\mathcal{P}}}} \left( U \right) A∈P(U) mean the same thing.

The definition of power sets is not particularly complicated, but the power set of the empty set feels slightly unintuitive to many learners at a first glance. Think through the following two exercises, and you should be fine.

Exercise 2.16

Find the mistake in the following claim: Because the empty set is a subset of every set (Theorem  2.13) and every set is a subset of itself (Theorem  2.14), P⁡(X)\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/powerset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#powerset}{\operatorname{\mathcal{P}}}} \left( X \right) P(X) must contain at least two elements for each set X.X\text{.}X.

The argument ignores that the empty set and the set itself could be one and the same. And indeed, P⁡(∅)={∅},\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/powerset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#powerset}{\operatorname{\mathcal{P}}}} \left( \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set}{\emptyset}} \right) \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} \left\lbrace \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set}{\emptyset}} \right\rbrace \text{,}P(∅)={∅}, a set which only contains a single element.

Theorem 2.39

Let A,BA, BA,B be sets. If P⁡(A)=P⁡(B),\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/powerset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#powerset}{\operatorname{\mathcal{P}}}} \left( A \right) \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/powerset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#powerset}{\operatorname{\mathcal{P}}}} \left( B \right) \text{,}P(A)=P(B), then A=B.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} B\text{.}A=B.

Proof of Theorem  2.39

We do a proof by contraposition, that is, we show that if A≠B,A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{\neq}} B\text{,}A=B, then P⁡(A)=P⁡(B).\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/powerset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#powerset}{\operatorname{\mathcal{P}}}} \left( A \right) \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{=}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/powerset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#powerset}{\operatorname{\mathcal{P}}}} \left( B \right) \text{.}P(A)=P(B). To that end, let A,BA, BA,B be sets with A≠B.A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{\neq}} B\text{.}A=B.

Without loss of generality, there is a∈Aa \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} Aa∈A such that a∉Ba \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\notin}} Ba∈/B (otherwise switch the roles of AAA and BBB). Then {a}∈P⁡(A) \left\lbrace a \right\rbrace \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\in}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/powerset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#powerset}{\operatorname{\mathcal{P}}}} \left( A \right) {a}∈P(A) (because {a}⊆A \left\lbrace a \right\rbrace \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\subseteq}} A{a}⊆A) but {a}∉P⁡(B) \left\lbrace a \right\rbrace \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_membership.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_membership}{\notin}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/powerset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#powerset}{\operatorname{\mathcal{P}}}} \left( B \right) {a}∈/P(B) (because {a}⊈B \left\lbrace a \right\rbrace \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/subseteq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#subseteq}{\nsubseteq}} B{a}⊈B), and thus P⁡(A)≠P⁡(B).\htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/powerset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#powerset}{\operatorname{\mathcal{P}}}} \left( A \right) \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_eq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_eq}{\neq}} \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/powerset.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#powerset}{\operatorname{\mathcal{P}}}} \left( B \right) \text{.}P(A)=P(B).

The proof of Theorem  2.39 contains the handy phrase without loss of generality, which indicates that only one of several distinct cases will be presented, because the other cases work in a similar way and can be handled through simple modifications to the presented argument. In this example, it is clearly not always true that AAA has a member that is not in B,B\text{,}B, as AAA could be a strict subset of B.B\text{.}B. But in that case, simply renaming AAA to BBB and vice versa correctly finishes the proof.

Quickly jotting down a without loss of generality (or w.l.o.g. for the particularly time-pressed mathematician) can often lead to overlooking crucial corner cases, leading to faulty proofs. Whenever you feel tempted to wlog your way out of a lengthy proof, ask yourself whether you can describe the necessary changes to cover all cases in one sentence. If yes, simply add that sentence to your proof. And if no, then you do not get to drop those convenient four words.

Conclusion

This concludes our first foray into set theory. Almost all of modern mathematics builds upon the notion of sets, with its predicates of membership, equality, and subsets, and the operations of intersection, union, set difference, and power set.

By now, you should be familiar with all of them, having both developed good intuition for them, and being able to define them precisely and work with those definitions. The proofs in this chapter rarely required a brilliant idea, but rather demonstrated the basic workflow of breaking down definitions and letting the structure of the statements in question guide their proofs. This alone will get you quite far, a significant part of mathematics is solid, unexciting craftsmanship. It might not be glamorous, but it yields good results.

Throughout the examples and exercises of this chapter, all specific sets contained finitely many elements. The definition of sets does not require this, it is perfectly fine for a set to contain infinitely many objects. All our proofs work perfectly fine for infinite sets. Infinite sets come with their own challenges however, starting with the simple question of how to even define an infinitely large object through a finite mathematic expression. The answers to that and several other problems are what we will cover in the next chapter.

This section contains a collection of exercises that touch upon all definitions of this chapter. Some introduce new but related definitions, so make sure to read through all the exercises even if you do not intend to solve all of them. Unlike the exercises throughout the chapter body, these exercises come without solutions. Write your own instead, and try to get feedback on them.

Definition 2.43: Symmetric Difference

Let A,BA, BA,B be sets. The symmetric difference of AAA and B,B\text{,}B, written as A△⁡B,A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/symmetric_difference.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#symmetric_difference}{\operatorname{\triangle}}} B\text{,}A△B, is the set of all objects which are elements of exactly one of AAA or B:B\text{:}B: A△⁡B≔(A∖B)∪(B∖A).A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/symmetric_difference.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#symmetric_difference}{\operatorname{\triangle}}} B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/defeq.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/deductive_reasoning.html#defeq}{\coloneqq}} \left( A \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_difference.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_difference}{\setminus}} B \right) \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/union.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#union}{\cup}} \left( B \htmlData{preview=http://localhost:1234/previews/set_difference.html}{\href{http://localhost:1234/sets.html#set_difference}{\setminus}} A \right) .A△B:=(A∖B)∪(B∖A).
